Am I not allowed to be the slightest bit negative without getting fucking permabanned? This game literally triggered the ban after being 14 day suspended, seriously Riot? I don't even understand how a person can say "Lmfao" without getting fucking chat restricted anymore.

replies.body:
Your entire chat is almost useless in terms of game strategy - the only useful thing you say is to kill veigar first and to counterjungle.

The *rest* of your chat log is you complaining about champions and how badly you dislike their ability to hurt you. You have multiple times you're harassing your team for their negativity by asking for reports on them. You harass your teammate for not using their ultimate by insinuating they're an idiot.

Considering your 14 day ban ended within the past few days, and you went immediately back to negative behavior, then Riot made good on what they told you what would happen if your negativity continued.

A chat should not be limited to game strategy. It's for chatting. Nor should the chat be solely positive. The chat is a way for players to talk to each other. 

Not talking about gameplay is not punishable.
Complaining about champions is not punishable.
Harassing the team and calling for reports is punishable. I agree with the OP's justification(not the one for calling the teammate an idiot), but Riot has firmly established their position on report-calling.

It just seems like the OP is the type who isn't inherently toxic, but just got more and more tilted as the game progressed from the combination of the players and the gameplay. People who aren't normally toxic (but provoked into that state) and getting punished by the system just doesn't seem right.
Complaining about champions is not inherently toxic. However, when a game's *entire* chat log is filled with it, it certainly is a negative attitude.
edgy
you said the games entire chat was like that. then no ban should have been issued for this game. this games chat should not be the example of the ban at least

How so? If not in the chat, they'll just complain about it in real life. You can see it in twitch streams when people complain about X being broken or bullshit (some even make entire videos).

If complaining about a champion is not inherently toxic, how can a chat log filled with it be negative attitude?

Who is it being negative towards? The only possible person who it could be directed towards is the player on the enemy team, and it seems that the OP is just ranting about it in chat.

If they want to complain in real life about it by screaming or other ways, fine. That doesn't affect anyone else in the game.

A message doesn't have to be inherently toxic for it to be used in a toxic manner. Saying "ugh I hate quinn she's so strong" a couple times? Not toxic. Spending the whole game railing on how it's lost because Quinn is too broken? Then it becomes negative attitude.

Gotta Agree with the people disagreeing with you . 

Complaining about a Champion isn't toxic. even if its a all game thing cause in truth there are a lot of characters in this game that are just ugh, because they can turn a tied with little to no effort " Examples :{{champion:45}} R, or {{champion:31}}  R , or even {{champion:157}} ."  its frustration 

NOW 

I will agree he should get banned cause from the start He was already Bashing on the enemy {{champion:45}} , and shaming him in all chat and even said he would report him cause he would hate to have the {{champion:45}}  on his team 

Now that I agree is poor sportsmanship .

and then to start picking on the Ezreal as well , and belittling his play style  yea negative there as well.


*******************************************

But then again this is one of the things I hate about Riots review System, the chat logs are horribly one sided seeming, cause we don't get the full chat log. 
we get only what the player said. 

there Should be a way to color code the chat logs or even. put a filter where it shows the champions Name instead of the players name and you get a Legend key that shows.. the what / who the reported character was playing so you can view the logs that way. 

I still firmly believe you guys can come up with a way better way to show report logs / reviews then what is currently being used.

> If they want to complain in real life about it by screaming or other ways, fine. That doesn't affect anyone else in the game.

And neither does complaning in the game. People in game will react to complaints the exact same way people in real life react to complaints, thus it isn't inherently negative. 

>A message doesn't have to be inherently toxic for it to be used in a toxic manner. Saying "ugh I hate quinn she's so strong" a couple times? Not toxic. Spending the whole game railing on how it's lost because Quinn is too broken? Then it becomes negative attitude.

The OP didn't say the game was lost, they just said that Veigar was bullshit. He complains about dying to veigar, and suggests the team to counter jg veigar and to focus him in teamfights.

The problem in the logs isn't the OP, it's the other people, who appear to be directly insulting the OP.

What does that mean, not normally toxic? You mean not toxic by default? What does it matter what you're like by default if you so easily shift into negative behavior? If you go on tilt whenever a game doesn't go your way, that is going to happen often enough that it's an issue, and your default attitude doesn't really matter.

Because you can't control yourself going on tilt. No matter what you do, you will go on tilt. What Riot punishes you is for releasing that tilt. You're going to channel the tilt somewhere in some way. The punishable way is through chat, but other effects, such as worse gameplay, or taking the anger/stress out in real life are just as unhealthy.

What causes the problem is the person/thing causing the tilt, not the person.

>  If you go on tilt whenever a game doesn't go your way, that is going to happen often enough that it's an issue, and your default attitude doesn't really matter.

It's not that simple. League, and generally MOBAs as a whole, have people become tilted much more easily than they would in other games. When I play with friends, I find that they, even if they're normally good people, will usually get tilted by something in the game.

You can control yourself when you start going on tilt. Plenty of people manage to do it every single day.

>It's not that simple.

It is that simple. I wouldn't claim that it's easy, but it is simple.

> League, and generally MOBAs as a whole, have people become tilted much more easily than they would in other games.

If you know that MOBAs send you over the edge and you can't handle them, then don't play them. If you know you're likely to get pissed off while playing a game and ruin the experience for everyone else, then the responsible choice is to not play the game. My friends and I have several games that we don't play at game night any more because, for one reason or another, people just get mad at each other. So we just don't play those games. If MOBAs aren't for you, they aren't for you. There's nothing wrong with deciding you can't handle them.

> You can control yourself when you start going on tilt. Plenty of people manage to do it every single day.

Everyone has a breaking point, and you can't change that point. You hold in the tilt as it approaches that point, but eventually, they will break. No one can do that every single day. That's literally impossible. Everyone has gotten angry before. The problem does not lie with the people, it is entirely the fault of what caused them to reach that tilting point.

It's not simple at all.

> If you know that MOBAs send you over the edge and you can't handle them, then don't play them. If you know you're likely to get pissed off while playing a game and ruin the experience for everyone else, then the responsible choice is to not play the game. My friends and I have several games that we don't play at game night any more because, for one reason or another, people just get mad at each other. So we just don't play those games. If MOBAs aren't for you, they aren't for you. There's nothing wrong with deciding you can't handle them.

You should never be forced out of a game because you can't handle the tilt from the community. Saying that is a very, very poor justification for toxicity in the game. "Don't like it? Get out" is your argument. A good game won't make you go over the edge. 

If your argument is true, then why the fck would anyone play this game? To get stressed? To get tilted? To get angry? 

If the game is driving you away, that is the game's fault, not the player's.

If your breaking point is "losing a game of League of Legends", you've got greater issue than the status of your League account.

>If your argument is true, then why the fck would anyone play this game? To get stressed? To get tilted? To get angry? 

For fun. Because some of us can handle it, and don't melt down over the game every time something doesn't go our way. And I get it, sometimes frustrating things happen in the game, and everyone gets upset at some point. But most people don't do it on a regular basis. And generally most of us don't reach the point of anger that we lose all control and just dive off the deep end. 

Maybe it is the games fault. But you don't get to control the game, or the community. You get to control yourself. And if you find yourself acting out again, and again, and again because of the game or the community, at some point it is your fault, because you keep going back to the situation that's causing you to act out.

Some people can't handle alcohol. If you're a bad drunk and can't handle it, you don't keep drinking and go, "It's not my fault, it's the alcohol's fault, so there's no reason for me to stop."

> If your breaking point is "losing a game of League of Legends", you've got greater issue than the status of your League account.

1. I don't think I ever mentioned anything about losing a game; think you were the one that brought it up


> For fun. Because some of us can handle it, and don't melt down over the game every time something doesn't go our way. And I get it, sometimes frustrating things happen in the game, and everyone gets upset at some point. But most people don't do it on a regular basis. And generally most of us don't reach the point of anger that we lose all control and just dive off the deep end.

I don't think you understand at all what I'm saying. You keep jumping to extremes and not looking at the broader picture.

People don't just get tilted over one little thing, it's more complex than that. There are a variety of causes/combination of causes. Yes, most people likely do get upset over something on a regular basis. I highly doubt anyone, whether they play this game or not, goes through a full week without being upset over something. When you lose control, you don't dive off the deep end. This, for instance, isn't even close to diving off the deep end. This is just someone being tilted. Diving off the deep end would be killing someone over the game. Which yes, actually has happened (look it up).

>Maybe it is the games fault. But you don't get to control the game, or the community. You get to control yourself. And if you find yourself acting out again, and again, and again because of the game or the community, at some point it is your fault, because you keep going back to the situation that's causing you to act out.

But when the majority of the community thinks this game is toxic, and people outside the game think of LoL as one of the most toxic online games to ever exist, there is very clearly something wrong about the game. Once again, you shouldn't be forced out of playing a game because of a toxic community/game.

This isn't just a person-to-person, or small minority. This applies to everyone who plays or potentially wants to play this game. If it were just a few people that were affected by this toxicity, I would be inclined to agree with you. But clearly, a significant number of people are being driven away by toxicity in this game and its community, whether it be through the system, or from quitting the game. Thus, the game/community are at fault.

> Some people can't handle alcohol. If you're a bad drunk and can't handle it, you don't keep drinking and go, "It's not my fault, it's the alcohol's fault, so there's no reason for me to stop."

The alcohol doesn't get to control itself. Poor analogy. LoL isn't an inanimate product

I think the problem is here, we disagree on the amount of control an average person has when they get upset. I keep going to extreme cases, because outside extreme case, I think an average person is still capable of (and responsible for) keeping their emotions in check. I consider going off the deep end losing control. If you are truly reaching the point that you cannot control yourself anymore, you've gone off the deep end. 

Also, I have looked it up and the only thing I can possibly find about people killing others over a game of League are unsubstantiated reports out of China, that may or may not actually involve league.

And last time I checked, while the community isn't, League itself is certainly an inanimate product.

No, if all "normal" people could control themselves, then there would literally be no negative emotions whatsoever, as they'd be controlled. It's not a matter of average person or extreme person, all people, no matter what, cannot control their emotions, all the time. It happens all the time, almost every day. No one is happy 100% of the time, and expresses themselves as such.

> Also, I have looked it up and the only thing I can possibly find about people killing others over a game of League are unsubstantiated reports out of China, that may or may not actually involve league.

Point being, people are willing to kill over video games. That's an extreme case.

> And last time I checked, while the community isn't, League itself is certainly an inanimate product.

It's animate because it's constantly changing, not something stationary.

What you seem to be missing is the fact that while we don't get to control our emotions, we don't have to be controlled by them either. Everyone gets angry. Not everyone lets that anger dictate their actions.

>It's animate because it's constantly changing, not something stationary.

That's not what animate means.

> What you seem to be missing is the fact that while we don't get to control our emotions, we don't have to be controlled by them either. Everyone gets angry. Not everyone lets that anger dictate their actions.

If you're getting angry, you're letting the anger out in through your actions.
What you seem to be missing is the repeated point that people have a breaking point.
For the millionth time:
You can control anger to some degree, but eventually, you will snap or lash out in some way. Some people will do it more often, and there is no way to solve this problem universally without removing the source.

> That's not what animate means

You know what I mean, you're just being obnoxious

>What you seem to be missing is the repeated point that people have a breaking point.

No. I get that. I also get that for most people, they don't go from zero to breaking point out of no where. For most people, it builds up, and they are capable of seeing themselves approaching their breaking point. It gives them time to avoid reaching that breaking point. 

If you find yourself reaching your breaking point on a regular basis, and instead of changing things and addressing why you're reaching your breaking point, you just continue to do the same thing, you are at fault. Once or twice is a mistake; After that, it's a willful decision to not change your behavior.

And yes, some times people get caught off guard; they have a bad day; they don't realize how close to snapping they are; etc. But you know what? Riot doesn't just ban people for having one game where they are frustrated and negative and bickering with teammates. They do so when it's a regular pattern of behavior; i.e., it happens a lot. If it's happening a lot, you need to step back and figure out why you're behaving the way you are, and come up with a plan to change that behavior. Because either you reach your breaking point too easily, or you're just using that as an excuse for acting like a child and not keeping your emotions in check.

>For the millionth time:
You can control anger to some degree, but eventually, you will snap or lash out in some way. Some people will do it more often, and there is no way to solve this problem universally without removing the source.

I know. I'm glad we're on the same page. I'll say it again:  If you get too upset playing League, and can't keep yourself from snapping, remove the source of your frustration, and stop playing League. It's that terribly simple. 

>You know what I mean, you're just being obnoxious

The fact that League changes superficially doesn't mean anything in regards to the analogy I made.

I'd love to give you an answer, but that thread is gone.

But for the most part, I kind of expect people to be able to keep their shit together for less than an hour.

> we need to focus on the people causing toxicity, rather than those who are getting triggered, offended, or tilted. 

Everyone always has an excuse for getting tilted. I've been raged at, called names, harassed, and accused of feeding in plenty of games where I was actually trying really hard, and doing fine. If you asked the people flipping out, I would bet money they would tell you it's because I was screwing them over in game. Because everyone always thinks they are justified to act like an ass. Seriously, look at almost every single thread in Player Behavior. Everyone always has a reason that they are fighting with their teammates. According to the boards, no one has ever started a fight either; it's only ever been "the other guy" that starts it. I have kids, I know how this works. I've been given that excuse more times than I care to remember. And the truth is, almost all the time, both people contribute to a fight.

Do people sometimes get set over the edge by an intentional troll trying to push their buttons? Yeah. And those trolls need to be dealt with. But you know what I see waaaaaaaaaaaaaay more often? Someone not playing particularly well, and another person on their team losing their shit over it. That_ is_ a problem, and it's not okay, and those are the people that actually contribute just as much, if not more, to the perception that League has the worst online community out there.

And you aren't ever going to be able to get rid of what's setting those sorts of people off, because they're ultimately getting tilted over things that are a natural part of the game, like... say.... losing. Yes, there's a lot that can change to make things better, and encourage healthier interactions with players. But none of those are quick fixes, and they require the community as a whole to realize the only way we make stuff better is to stop acting out ourselves.

> If Riot uses your logic

Riot doesn't need to use my logic, each individual player that can't control themselves needs to. That's whats going to change things: When people start changing themselves. Riot sends a message when they give you a chat restriction, or they suspend your account: Your behavior isn't acceptable. It's up to each individual to listen to that message, and deal with it the best way they can. For some that means recognizing what they've done wrong, and changing their behavior accordingly. For others, that means recognizing that they can't,  or are unwilling to, behave by the guidelines they've been given, and choosing to walk away until they can or will do so.

Riot isn't going to change the community on it's own. We need to change it ourselves as part of the community. That starts with each individual taking personal responsibility for their choices.

>The alcohol, when you buy it, has already been set in stone, and can't be changed anymore. 

And when you go into a game, it's already set in stone. It can't be changed any more. Just because something can change in the future doesn't mean it's changing now, or any time soon.

[Here's a random scenario that I found just by randomly looking into gameplay](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/gameplay-balance/c9lh9fVL-2-days-in-and-ive-just-been-trolled-for-30-straight-minutes-in-a-normal)

Do you really expect someone to just sit in a game for 20-40ish minutes bottling their tilt and emotions?

> If you find yourself reaching your breaking point on a regular basis, and instead of changing things and addressing why you're reaching your breaking point, you just continue to do the same thing, you are at fault. Once or twice is a mistake; After that, it's a willful decision to not change your behavior.

But it is usually not you causing yourself to reach that breaking point. The "why" is because of other people, bringing me back to my original point: that we need to focus on the people causing toxicity, rather than those who are getting triggered, offended, or tilted.  

There is no way to make yourself tilt less easily or be less emotional, that's just something natural. It's a personality type. The way you get about reducing the outbursts is suppression, which is unhealthy. The system gives too much power to people that cause tilt and too much pressure on their victims.

>I know. I'm glad we're on the same page. I'll say it again: If you get too upset playing League, and can't keep yourself from snapping, remove the source of your frustration, and stop playing League. It's that terribly simple.

That will solve the problem, but that's still a terrible solution. League is a source of frustration to many people. From new players joining "one of the most toxic online communities" to the experienced players you can see constantly complaining online, there is constant frustration. If Riot uses your logic, the playerbase will decline, and, because everyone left is supposedly "thick-skinned," there will be more toxicity going around, since Riot would no longer consider the "special snowflakes." The argument for "just stop getting so triggered" doesn't really hold anymore.


> The fact that League changes superficially doesn't mean anything in regards to the analogy I made.

The alcohol, when you buy it, has already been set in stone, and can't be changed anymore. League can be changed by Riot, before you "consume" it.

I'm on your fucking side dude. These people responding "ohh you were on thin ice it doesnt matter how you used it" are actual jokes. You do not deserve a fucking perm ban LMFAO. It's a bot that just bans people off of certain keywords. I got perm banned for calling a TROLL INTING MY GAME a fa**ot. I want it to where people look through chat logs themselves. This bot is fucking people over so bad. You should definitely get unbanned.

That's not how it works at all. Keywords are not a part of the system save for some certain extremely toxic words (racism, homophobia, sexism, other hate speech, telling someone to kill themselves, etc).

More than likely, the OP here was punished for their *constant* negativity over *many* games, and after being warned with a 14 day ban recently where it explicitly states that they would be permanently suspended if negativity continued.

Riot, the League community, and society as a whole would disagree with you. Some words have been so commonly used to disparage someone based on an unchangeable aspect of themselves (sex, sexuality, race, etc) that that is their only (or primary) meaning to the point that they are unacceptable for use in public discourse.
:) There's no reason that people shouldn't be civil.. we're all entitled to our opinions regardless how unpopular/popular they are, regardless of how many others agree with us.

> [{quoted}](name=Chermorg,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=uiiEKGof,comment-id=0001000100000000,timestamp=2017-11-04T03:56:19.804+0000)

I don't think you should say society as a whole. That's unfair. You don't speak for me, I am a part of society and I disagree with you. So let's keep it real, don't speak for others' opinions in such a generalizing way please.

"Society as a whole" is what I said to represent the *general* opinion of society. It is inevitable that in a large society such as human society that there will be those who disagree with the widely held majority opinion. That does not change the fact that the general opinion of society is still the opinion of society as a whole.

I understand that. But a lot of the time, society gives an appearance that would lead you to think it is the general opinion, when it's not. Think about Clinton v Trump. I think society as a whole had you thinking generally people preferred Hillary, yet Trump won. And even as president, it almost still seems to be the narrative that everyone hates Trump. When it comes to thoughts and opinions like that, I don't think you have enough data or knowledge to say "society as a whole", because you might get your information from sources that tend to lean towards one way or another. Yet, even though that is a very vocal minorty, you would still think it's the majority of people who think that way. You know what I mean? I've lost the original point anyways, and I don't feel like refreshing myself on the topic so I will concede. I just wanted to point that out. A lot of those with an opinion these days that can be easily misconstrued, just don't speak at all, over the fear of people taking it the wrong way and labelling the person as some sort of monster.

Okay okay, I looked again. Deriving hate from a word. Yes a lot of social media would lead you to believe society as a whole would disagree and they would say you CAN derive hate from a word. Such as, f****t. Yet, in REAL LIFE, not that fake, social media, high horse shit that people get onto, I hear f****t being used all the time by people who claim to have no hatred towards gay people whatsoever. I hear gay people call eachother f****ts. Some just grew up saying it and they don't make the connection between the hateful ways it was used back in the day. They call their straight friends f****ts,  yet they would never say it to a gay person, because they don't actually want to hurt gay people. No one is gonna argue this on Facebook. So it really depends where you're getting your information.

Obviously, there are generally accepted ideas, but those can't be things like "Deriving hate from a word". It just cant. Generally accepted things would be like, no one wants to get punched in the face. You can't say anyone who says f****t, hates gay people. You can say, society as a whole says it's not okay to kidnap a child and murder them.  So if one gay man calls another gay man a ft, how can that be if society as a whole has decided that that word is purely a hateful word? Gay people hate gays? Or is it merely a silly word with a very negative history that some latch onto, while others do not? I don't think you can fairly say "society as a whole" in this situation.

Just my opinion, and I understand if you disagree. I'm kind of skeptical of a lot that goes on in society these days and the way things are represented. Our sources of information can be VERY misleading and sort of meant as a way of telling you what to think, not what people actually do think.

Glad we agree, a person's ACCOUNT, where they spend 100's on dollars on, shouldn't be reviewed by a fucking computer. It should be reviewed by an actual HUMAN BEING. I cannot even tell you how many times I've been chat restricted across multiple accounts for reinstating what a player said. It's fucking bullshit.

1. You aren't supposed to threaten reports I don't think
2. You used the word "idiot" regardless of context the bot will ban you (it's a fucking bot my dude)
3. You could maybe contest it but um... you better suck riot's dick to get it done.

I'm gonna get punished for using the word "idiot"? What kind of system is that? Also, it wasn't used as a threat, he was deliberately being an asshole all game, so I simply stated "Reporting" to let him know. I could've been a much bigger of an asshole, but I tried MY BEST to keep it cool and not flame. Look where that got me.
Believe it or not, thats how Riots system works. You could be permabanned for that.

Needs to be addressed. Why on Earth would anyone spend money on this game if you can get banned for using the word "idiot"? "Oh, Draven used the word idiot, best shut him down before he gets started".

Most people won't get banned for it. You did however because you were already a toxic person beforehand and were on thin ice. This is why you were banned. If I go into game right now. And spam "idiot" in chat, there is a very very very unlikely outcome that I'll be perma'd. I might get a chat restriction if I annoy my teammates enough, but I won't get perma'd. You want to know why? Because I wasn't fresh off a 14 day suspension. I still have 2 levels of "naughty" before I get banned. Unless I do something incredibly drastic like tell my team to off themselves.
Riot gives you 14 days to cool off, yes I admit to being an ass before. But, I shouldn't get the "thin ice" punishment. I literally used a word equivalent to "dummy head" and got punished for it.

Why? You get in trouble at work or anywhere in real life, someone is going to be keeping a close eye on your behaviour, regardless of what you did. If you were in sports in highschool, if you got kicked out of a game for poor sportsmanship (or sent home from practice for whatever reason), that coach was gonna be on your ass for a few weeks to make sure you didn't do it again. And if you slipped up, you're off the team. Riot implements that same thought process.

Is this real life? No. Is your boss a computer? No. I don't see your argument here. Also, Riot doesn't implement anything towards my account being suspended. A bot does, one that automatically triggers restrictions via trigger words. _**I could be calling my friend a "goof ball", the computer doesn't know I'm joking around, let alone can it not detect tone or sarcasm, which is why it's a flawed system.**_

But is your friend going to report you? Likely not. People in the game are likely not going to be reporting you for joking around with your friend. However, if what you are saying can be offensive to other players and they do report you, then again, that's your problem. If you want to rage/joke/whatever do it in voice comms so you don't get in trouble.

My point was explaining WHY you get the "thin ice" punishment. Riot uses the ban bot to scan millions of reports. If you are unhappy with your well deserved punishment, feel free to contact them.
